column8: Stunning and Refreshing Visit to Ravana Ella Falls
column11: Visiting Ravana Ella Falls was an incredible experience! The waterfall is breathtaking, surrounded by lush greenery and a serene natural environment. The sound of the cascading water and the cool mist made it feel incredibly refreshing and peaceful. The walk to the falls was enjoyable, with beautiful scenery along the way. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for nature lovers and photography enthusiasts, offering stunning views from different angles. Our guide, Sithum, made the visit even more special by sharing interesting stories and local legends about the falls, which added a cultural touch to the natural beauty. Overall, Ravana Ella Falls is a must-visit when exploring the Ella region. It‚Äôs a wonderful combination of nature, tranquility, and breathtaking scenery an experience I‚Äôll always remember.

Ravana Falls is a highlight of any tour through Sri Lanka‚Äôs stunning hill country, and it's always a pleasure to guide visitors to this magnificent natural wonder. As a guide, I find that Ravana Falls never fails to impress with its sheer beauty and serene setting. The waterfall itself is a striking sight, cascading gracefully over rugged rocks into a crystal-clear pool below. The backdrop of lush green forest adds to the enchantment, creating a picturesque scene that's perfect for both relaxation and photography. One of the best aspects of Ravana Falls is its accessibility. It‚Äôs just a short walk from the main road, making it an easy stop for travelers of all ages and abilities. Whether visitors are looking to dip their toes in the cool waters or simply enjoy the view from the observation point, the experience is both enjoyable and hassle-free. I particularly love sharing the local legends and cultural significance associated with Ravana Falls. The story of King Ravana, a central figure in Sri Lankan folklore, adds a layer of intrigue and connection to the site. It‚Äôs always rewarding to see visitors appreciate not just the natural beauty but also the rich cultural context. For those traveling through the Ella region or seeking a tranquil spot to unwind, Ravana Falls is a must-visit. Its natural charm and easy accessibility make it a perfect addition to any itinerary. The walk can be a bit hair raising as traffic goes fast around steep bends but the views are stunning! We also saw monkeys along the way which was great. The falls themselves are beautiful but not the easiest to climb towards from the road and very busy. You are in full view of the main road as well so it‚Äôs not that relaxing! The name of the falls is derived from the legendary king Ravana, the fall is on the road side and above which is the Ravana Cave which is said to have housed Sita. There is a small trek which leads to it. The weather was against us to even get off our vehicle so trek to the cave was out of question. The legend has it that Ravana hid Sita here on the cave and the pond with the falls is where she used to take bath. On a good day the water can be quite a rush and gushing.

This gorgeous waterfall is situated closer to Ell-Wellawaya road 1km after Ella town. It is 40m in height and falls in steps. Even in a dry day it appears beautifully. It is more beautiful after the rain.Though it is called as Rawana Falls, correct term is Bambaragama Falls. But be careful in climbing over the fall or bathing there as it cost more than 20lives upto now.
A nice place to stop at when travelling past but not worth paying for a tuk tuk to go out and back from town.

falls are well worth seeing in all seasons but are incredibly powerful and dramatic after seasonal rains. The local environment is very beautiful and it is wonderful to watch the water crashing down on to the rocks with a backcloth of trees and mountains. A bridge at the foot of the falls is a very popular tourist stopping place and there are several places around.

About 15-20 mins drive out of Ella, these are lovely falls but I would only visit if you are travelling past - unless you REALLY like waterfalls. Our driver stopped here on way from Yala to Ella. It was the weekend so was extremely busy.  Lots of Sri Lankans having a wonderful time and a large handful of tourists like us!! No entrance fee - just a very short walk off the road (we just had thongs on) or you can simply look at the falls from your car. There is a lovely 'pool' area about halfway up the falls, which looked fantastic for a refreshing dip on a hot day. Alas we didn't have suitable clothes (although lots of kids were in there fully dressed) but there were plenty of spots to dip your feet too. It is open and rocky as well and my son (13) had great fun climbing up even higher. Down by the road were many temporary stalls selling trinkets, food and drinks.  We bought some corn on the cob - fantastic.  Spent about 30 mins there.

This is a stunning waterfall and is only 5-10 meters off the road which is good for easy viewing but if you‚Äôre like us and we‚Äôre hoping for a quick dip in the water it‚Äôs pretty busy and being so close to the road made us a little less comfortable to swim. Check it out for yourself :)

I would recommend a quick visit to the falls. They are very easily accessible from the side of the road. Provided you are careful and avoid climbing the side of the falls (you will be told off by the guards anyway), there is no problems having a swim in the pool at the bottom of the cascade.

Really nice place with awsome waterfalls view.  But really, really many people there and arround.  Not possible to parking somewhere around.  Many people everyvhere so to take good photo is almost impossible  üòÄüòÄüòÄ no try to buy something there because prices are really high!
WOW! an awesome waterfall.  An easy walk to the area you can have a swim if you wish. Take your bathers for a dip.

We drove past this on the way to Ella and our driver stopped so we could have a quick look and take a couple of photos. Waterfall is well seen from the road from road but couldn't be bothered going any further. Worth while having a quick stop as you are going by but not worth a special trip unless you want to get up into the falls.
Eye catching waterfall in Ella.. A best place but you can't do the things You want..'cuz itz dangerous... be careful if your travelling with kids.
The falls are great, but not those by the road. Go to the upper ones (Ravana's secret) which you can swim in! Recommend hiking from Amba tea estate (also great!!)

We drove past this on the way to Ella and our taxi driver stopped so we could have a quick look. Waterfall viewpoint from road is nice but we didn‚Äôt get to explore any further. Such a easy way to get from Ella you can either get a tuk tuk or go via local bus which stops directly opposite the waterfall. Great to chill and enjoy the view. You will also find a few of the shops around

Beautiful fall surrounded mountains. Nice place to stop and take a nice photo shot. In this place there are many sellers so you can buy some souvenirs or food if you needed we did not buy anything because its looks cheap and not necessary.

We visited on a holiday Sunday, and the natural pool near the bottom of the falls was chock-full of locals (all men) swimming and splashing.  There was also a smaller pool to the side that had women and children using it.  It was a marvelous sight to see!
A waterfall. Nothing special, not secluded, no beautiful nature around. You cannot really swim because it‚Äôs forbidden. Very touristy for reasons which escape me.
Almosphere is wonderful. You feel very cooling when you reach there, scenery too around the place is amazing.

We paid a ruk-tuk 1000 Rs for a tour for the town to the waterfall then he waited till we where done. The waterfall is super fine but there is nothing much to see other than that. Its hard to go for a small swim since there is no where to jump in.
Overall worth seeing, car parking could be improved a bit so should be the food stalls. everything else is just good.
What a wonderful sight as you turn the corner and see these wonderful falls. They are very popular with tourists, hence the people selling fruit and other things.

This is a lovely stop on the way to southern Sri Lanka. Its quick stop by the road to take few pictures. May be its the time we went but it was a bit crowded on the day we were there and even to take a picture it was not so good. But as said its a lovely waterfall with a quick stop.

It is located along the roadside and takin the best picture from roadside ! Watch out  for the car too. However, hard to access to the water site if you plan to soak into he water. No proper waking path way to get there. Slippery and can be dangerous. You need a guide to bring you here so is easier than any public transport!

This is just on the main road from Ella to Wellawaya. If you do not have a car you can travel by public transport. As always when you are near the falls it will be very refreshing. Couple of eateries available near by ( small joints ) but we found less items available for eating since it was a holiday and we reached there after 5 p.m., Nothing much else. You can stop for a couple of photos when you are traveling down south from Ella.
We passed by on our way to Udawalawe National Park and stopped for a photo. It was fairly high, but coming from Canada it was not a show stopper for us.
We saw it with blue sky and after a rain fall with a lot of water coming down. You can do it also on your way south and does not require a separate Tuk-Tuk drive.

walking distance from hotel but on our way back took a bus. lot of people. difficult to take photograph. but this is very good nature

Good one, but lack basic facilities to spend time more, need lighting in the nights to view. Dangerous to get down and take bath. Water flow is heavy and not able to take photograph since the water droplets flows till the road.
Subtract the road and you will feel like heaven, especially when it is raining. Lot of small small falls along.
Nice place for take a break, beautiful waterfall If you are close to this place you have to see it, i was really impressed

We visited the place after a long rainy night. Therefore, we could not go up the mountain. Be aware of the monkeys and dogs. Notice: Monkeys can and may grab your items so be on the watch out for them and specially close all car windows. Place is refreshing and blessed for those honeymooners... enjoy Sri Lanka.

Our taxi driver stopped here on the way to Ella so that we could take a picture and 2 minutes was all we needed. Nice Fall that was exceptionally strong due to the rain. If you are passing by, it is worth seeing. If not, it is not worth going to that area just to see it
Stopped of here during our tour that was very conveniently right by the main road. Spectacular falls that are used by locals to wash and cool down during the hottest part of the day.

Another amazing and beautiful waterfall in Sri Lanka. It's rather conveniently located where you can reach it by side of Ella - Wellawaya main road. Anyone who passes by get the eye-catching view of it and makes your heart fall for it quite easily. the place was great,but there were no enough garbage bins provided,so public has left rubbish everywhere in the place which was very sad,but there are people who collect money from the vehicles who stop there to see the waterfall,they say they are from the government,but nothing has been done to save the envoronment

Ravana Falls in Ella, technically has a height of 25m, but is made up of many beautiful cascades making it appear much higher. Situated right beside the road to Ella, it is easy to spot and is worth stopping and admiring.

Stopped here as part of a trip to Ravena‚Äôs Cave. Lots of locals using it to shower from. It‚Äôs free to access and you can see it from the side of the road, about a 10 min Tuk Tuk out of Ella. We stopped here to have some corn and raw mangoes while enroute from nuwara Eliya to yala . The falls in totality are nothing great but one can have some decent roadside snack and it's worth a pit stop

Beautiful waterfalls which falls inbetween the rocks from the mountains. Falls can be viewed just stopping by the road. Location is very close from Ella drive. Must to visit while you are in in Ella region

I really enjoyed coming here, I love waterfalls. Something about that rushing water is meditative. I came a day after heavy rain so there was a lot of rushing water, and loads of locals and tourists alike. It's really easy to get here on the local bus from Ella, and super cheap and fast at 50 rupees RT/10 mns. I can't think of a reason not to do it.

Ravana falls has a historical importance in the story of Ravana. There are food vendors along the sides of the road near the attraction . If you are passing by you have to stop and have a little sour mango and chili while admiring this marvel and heading on to Ella
Lovely to look at and swimming  is available. Tuk tuk there and back or walk down from Ella, if you like to play dodge with the traffic. You can also walk there along the train track.

Lovely waterfalls, you can easily walk in and take some stunning pictures and enjoy the views! No entrance charge or anything like that. If you are driving past you can stop nearby and take pictures from over the bridge and enjoy the view without having to get wet! Luckily when we went it was crowded!

We visited last week during the new year holidays and it was very busy with holidaying Sri Lankans. It's quite a spectacle but only for 10 minutes of your time. It was deceptive how far it was from town and we quickly gave up walking and got a tuk tuk. It's not worth the walk from town! Road is too steep, long and dangerous.

I don't think this will consume your entire day, but worth stopping to take some pictures and also dip you feet in the waterfall, especially if you're travelling with little ones. There is a cost associated with entry - i think its 40 rupees for local people and about 150/200 rupees for foreigners.

We stopped off here for a few minutes en route to 98 Acres Hotel. It was really busy as it was the Sri Lankan New Year holiday and the main view point is from the main road so it gets very congested. That said, it's a great view

Do stop by to have a look, and maybe a quick dip. The dip may not be possible if high season is in swing. Locals also bathe/shower here. Be prepared to pay some random person for parking if you're driving. I was travelling with locals, and even they were taken by the fact that there was a cost to park in an otherwise unsigned area.
We  had  to  pay 1000 lkr  for 2 was  nice  a   cave  finally  with  lots  of bats inside  was   a  nice  climb weather was  drizziling during the climb.

Lovely waterfall, down in the valley near Ella - 10-15 minute tuk-tuk down. Sellers aren't very intrusive down here, so you can enjoy the view in relative peace. Loads of monkeys in the trees and bushes, so mind your belongings!
this falls are really nice, you can easily reach them by bus from Ella, it is like 10-15 min ride. only negative is that the falls are really close to the mail road
The curant is to strong to bath or sit in in it. We just watched from the streets that all. Just  stop, watch the waterfall and take a picture and leave.

This waterfall was on our way so glad we stopped off. Picturesque and easily accessible. What was supposed to be a quick photo stop ended up as a two hour splash. My 8 year old son absolutely loved splashing in the waterfall, the different levels provided a great obstacle course for him. He did not want to leave, highlight of the holiday for him, the monkey taking his corn was bonus adventure for him.
There are better and bigger falls.  Just stop for a few minutes on the way from Ella to Tissa fo a photo.  No charge for a photo!

We took the bus here from the centre of Ella (the 998), that said any bus heading south is likely to head passed the waterfall, just wave down any bus anywhere and ask the driver/conductor. we were heading to thissamaharama after ella wellawaya road u will see this.Nice place to visit and nice water fall.

It is 6km from Ella to the Falls and, as I had nothing better to do, I thought I could do with an invigorating walk. My advice? A brief visit which I wished we had more time to explore and perhaps have quick paddle. Easy to access.

The waterfall itself is beautiful and you can also do some bathing in the cool water. But it seems to be a spot for western tourists to go bathing there. A lot of locals sell foods and drinks from their little huts.
The waterfall is nice to see but not really a must see. Travelling south you ll pass them anyway. Just stop and have a short look. No enterance fee.
These waterfalls were just stunning   People swimming, and locals selling hot corn on the cob and picnicking, cooking up their rice on the side of the road, very interesting!  Plenty of tourists!

Awesome waterfall. You can have a little swim if you want to. Tip: it's a 10min bus ride from Ella town (25 rupees per person). Tuk tuk will charge around 500 rupees! The lady at a stall just next to the bus stop will tell you when the next bus will come!
Stunning watefall, worth a visit, Both sides of the road   to look at, Be careful of the traffic, Amazing  site

A waterfall with grate views ! Many photographic locations. However , do not try to climb the waterfall or make any risky moves . This place has a high rate of accidents. Just sit back and enjoy the views

For some reason i feel that if the waterfall was a hike away oe something, it'd be more amazing but it's just a waterfall by the road. You wont find yourself spending too much time here. Few picks with the waterfall and monkeys and thats it

Its a short bus ride from town which will cost you around 20 Rs. Many people would walk to this from center (some 6 7 km). Nothing special here. Just the regular fall with nothing much to offer. Do it if you have some free time and nothing else to do.
Amazing falls with great swimming and views! Very quiet and a real amazing place. If you can get to the abandoned tea factory above the falls that is really worth a visit too.

It is a medium sized waterfall just by the Ella to Udawale highway. So no need to plan separately, you can just park the car by the roadside and the spend some time there. But there is no stairs or roaps available. So, it is very risky to move closer to the waterfall to have fill of the water.
not sure if id make the trip for the photo alone, we were passing anyway so stopped for 10 mins for a photo and some coconut water.  watch out for the monkeys!

Stunning waterfall right by the road traveling north towards Ella, easy to access! Lots of monkeys to see, but was heartbroken to see a very hungry little dog who looked like he was in great discomfort, he had hardly any fur!
It's a nice looking waterfall yes. But it's on a main road, not secluded. We went there to swim but it's not a safe place to swim with kids. Been 6 deaths there according to sign.
As we were driving to Yala National Park we stopped to see the falls.  Very nice.  Worth the time to take ii in.  I think that there might be some short hiking trails but am not sure.

Easy to access from Ella- grab any bus heading out of centre and down the hill. They run frequently and cost 40r/s. Tell the driver ravana falls. Look up Diyaluma falls.... it‚Äôs the reason this was given a 3/5. Looks better after a good shower of rain and not sure about other times of day but between 2-4 it was full of people!
We just went to take picutres. As you cand o so easily from the road. There were however a few people swimming. Much bigger than expected
Good swim in the cold water, and beautiful waterfall and surroundings. The rocks are very slippery so be careful!!

I intended to walk to the falls but the road was very busy so i opted to catch the bus for the 6 km trip. There was no mistaking where to get off the bus as the falls were right next to the road , along with snack stalls and souvenir stalls, and crowds of people. The falls came down the mountain cascading in to several pools, one of which people were bathing in. I guess it would have been quite cold in the pool. We were not allowed to climb up the hill by the side of the falls as it was too dangerous, in fact a sign warned us that over 30 people had died at the falls. I stood and admired the falls for 30 minutes before catching the bus back to Ella.
Just 5-6 kilometers from Ella town. Enjoy it but adhere to the nature rules...!! Rocks may be bit slippery so mind your steps :)
Probably the most spectacular of the many waterfalls we saw in SL. Evan good souvenir shopping at the stalls nearby. Certainly worth a visit!
You will definitelly enjoy great refreshment after visiting Ella rock or Little adams peak. You can get there and back by a tuk tuk for like 1000 rupies.
A nice waterfall along the road, nice stop on our tour around Sri Lanka. There was some tourist here but not much.

Stopped  en-route south to see this waterfall as I had heard it was fab. Well, really is is a smallish waterfall with a sort of "plunge pool" at its base, full of westerners. It is really nothing special - but made a useful pit stop in our journey. If it had not been at the side of the road, I would not have stopped.
We visited the Falls twice in two weeks it was an amazing experience the second time they had been torrential rain so the waterfall looked amazing

Not much to say, really. It's a waterfall with a natural pool just next to the main road. Which is how we found it by coincidence as we were exploring on our rented scooter. Unless you feel like jumping in the pool for a cool-down I'd say it's best for just taking in the touristy scene (popular with both locals and tourists). If on a scooter, beware of the parking dude trying to charge you 200 for a 20 rupees parking fee ticket (the price is printed on the receipt) and the pushy dude trying to sell you some piece of rock by forcing it into your hands. Now, you kinda get the scene... Come to think about it, the monkeys on the main road down to the fall are way more fun to stop and watch. The macqaces(?) will let you get really close. They are curious and well behaved but the ones with white beards and black faces are much more shy. But we found watching them even more interesting. You may have to venture down some of the side roads to find them, though.
If you are nearby the waterfalls, so stop for a swim in the water, or just wet your feet. It's so nice and cooling. You can bring children for this. Maybe you'll see the monkeys. We did..

This spot gets busy with visitors. Parking is on the road. You won‚Äôt have to walk far to get to see the waterfall as it is straight off the road. Be careful of the traffic on the road. It is not advisable to feed the monkeys. There are a couple of souvenir places with decent prices. Didn‚Äôt try the restaurant/snack place.

Nice little waterfall, nothing breathtaking. I was with my 1 year old daughter so had to keep hold of her hand, which is fine. It‚Äôs by a road too so it‚Äôs not too peaceful. There is no walking or hiking here, I wouldn‚Äôt go out of my way to see it.
Attractive roadside waterfall which you can also bathe in. Some paid parking available but free to view. Worth a stop and photo.
The best of this waterfall is its location on the way down from Ella towards the plains, also passing little Adam's peak. They are nice but not particularly impressive.
The falls are breathtaking we stopped had a little walk  was beautiful scenery  there‚Äôs a few points you can go  you can walk up also from the road. There is resteraunt food lovley fresh
A very picturesque location, the upper falls are easily visible from the road, limited parking but well worth stopping for.
Right on the highway from Ella to Southern Sri Lanka, this waterfall is mighty due to its height. But it is just work a quick stop due to running traffic on that road.
Lots of people doing the same thing, lovely water fall and a place the locals go to shower. Dont have the boiled corn if you are tempted, go for the grilled.

the valley road crosses about half way up the falls so you get a very easy and good view from the roadway. I imagine it will be very impressive in the wet season when the water levels are up but still impressive in February. Don't climb the rocks though. Can be very dangerous as the signs will tell you.

The waterfall is on the way from Ella south to the Sri Lanka beaches and you can‚Äòt miss it. It is a delightful stop and if you take you bathing suit you can stand under the waterfall. Just be very very careful since it is very slippery and you can easily fall and hurt yourself.

Our tour guide took us to this waterfall . It‚Äôs not possible to see the falls unless you stop and have lunch in the alongside Hotel. The views were something else!
Just being there made me happy. A wonderful waterfall with a relaxed atmosphere. Whether you want to have a little swim or just sit with your feet in the water, its your choice

Sadly right next to the main road with all its noise and traffic.. added to that the amount of rubbish dumped around is a disgrace. Walk a little way away from the masses and use a telephoto to get more natural shots.

In the realm of waterfalls, was kinda disappointingly small, but very picturesque nonetheless. Plus it's right by the side of the road on your way out of Ella (if you take the road option) and well worth a quick stop. The water is great. Get a drink!
Literally on the side of the road so you may just end up there in passing. Take swimming attire and a towel.
Go if it's on your way, don't, if it isn't. Just a small waterfall nxt to a road with a lot of people around
It‚Äôs easy to visit these Falls from Ella. Take a bus or tuktuk. You can have a swim or just take in the view. There are many stalls nearby trying to sell trinkets and food.

Good views from the main road Unfortunately the bottom of the falls is spoiled by the number of tourist tat stalls that have sprung up We went in late February and the water levels were low so not as dramatic as they must be in the monsoon
Nice place where you can ser lots of monkeys, however, local people tend to have a bath with soaps making it unattractive for tourists to get into the water. However, worth seeing.

There were a lot of people here getting photos and various touts on the road but it was still an impressive sight and as its on the road doesn't take up much time. my preference would be to stay at the Ravanas secret estate and swim in the residents only pools at the top of the falls,

We had a brief stop here on the way to Tangalle. What was seemingly a small water fall from far turned out to be one magnificent water fall just across the main road. There were hundreds of people/school kids lined up and taking pictures. You see this effortlessly.
This is a nice waterfall with plenty of backpackers coolling off in the pool at the base. It is easy to see from the road.
It is quite a climb to get to the natural pool. But quite fun. And it is always nice to have a refreshing waterfall dip.
